The main thing:â–ªDigital currency is recognized as property;â–ªMining and sale of digital currency will not be subject to VAT;â–ªThe operator of the mining infrastructure will have to report to the tax authorities who uses its services to issue cryptocurrency. If such information is not transmitted on time, a fine of 40 thousand rubles will be imposed;â–ªIn terms of personal income tax payment, the digital currency obtained through mining will be classified as income in kind;â–ªThe value of the resulting currency will be determined by market quotes. Such income will be taxed on the usual progressive scale, taking into account tax deductions in the amount of mining expenses;â–ªIncome from the acquisition, sale or other circulation of digital currency will be taxed on a two-stage scale of personal income tax rates (13% in relation to income within 2.4 million rubles and 15% for income exceeding this amount);â–ªThe patent system and regime are not applied to mining and transactions with digital currency self-employed.

Title: Fraudsters have prepared a number of schemes to steal the data of...
Description: Fraudsters have prepared a number of schemes to steal the data of Russians on Black Friday. This was reported to TASS by experts in the field of information security. Title: â†©ï¸ The German Foreign Ministry regrets the US decision to supply ...
Description: TASS: The Pentagon has admitted that future deliveries of military aid to Ukraine will include shipments of anti-personnel mines, the press service reported. The German Foreign Ministry regrets the US decision to supply anti-personnel mines to Kyiv and the position of Ukraine, which believes that they will give it an advantage in the conflict. This was stated by the representative of the German Foreign Ministry Christian Wagner.

Title: ğŸ–¼ Ukraine and Poland were not against Germanyâ€™s import of Russia...
Description: Ukraine and Poland were not opposed to Germany importing Russian gas because they received payment for its transit, Merkel told Der Spiegel magazine. She noted that back in 2015, it 'did not seem reasonable to talk about severing all economic ties' with Russia. Many in Europe shared the same position, and 'it was quite difficult to convince EU partners of the need to introduce at least some sanctions' against Russia.
